descriptionProfile: Discovering and telling stories from around the world. Founded in 2010 by @kevin and @mikeyk.

posts.description:
Photo by @bryrclogs 
After working as a designer in the fashion industry for 15 years, Isobel Schofield started Bryr Clogs (@bryrclogs) in 2012. ‚ÄúI felt that there was a better way to make things that was responsible, ethical and connected,‚Äù says Isobel, whose company makes every pair of clogs to order in their San Francisco workshop. ‚ÄúSince the very beginning, I‚Äôve connected with my community through Instagram. I shoot all our photos and stories on my phone, capturing real moments from life in the studio and out in the world. I believe that being authentically ourselves, and showing what we do and why we love it, brings like-minded people to us.‚Äù
Isobel‚Äôs advice to new businesses trying to build a presence on Instagram? ‚ÄúBe real and be true to who you are and what you believe in.‚Äù
Watch as Isobel and her team construct a pair of their signature clogs on today‚Äôs story for #SmallBizSat.

Featured photo @rrrudya
Weekend Hashtag Project: #WHPsquares
This weekend it‚Äôs time to think (in or) outside the box. The challenge is to make images and videos that play with variations on the square, as in this featured photo from Alina Rudya (@rrrudya).
Here are some tips:
Start with the shape. Find or create patterns using squares. A checkerboard floor, a tall building with a grid of shuttered windows, or even a random configuration of three-dimensional cubes could all be fun starting points for your submission.
Try a new angle. Get creative with new perspectives. For example, place your subject in the corner of a square room and have them stretch out to fill the extremities of a life-sized square frame; set your friend atop of an oversized cube; or use a square frame within your image to draw attention to your desired point of focus.
Be playful. Revisit your childhood for inspiration. Think of games like tic-tac-toe, hopscotch and chess that are all based around the square. Or go outside of the box and use your imagination! Build an environment out of colorful blocks, or turn a cardboard box into a rocket and have your pet go for ride. üöÄ
PROJECT RULES: Please add the #WHPsquares hashtag only to photos and videos shared over this weekend and only submit your own visuals to the project. By adding the #WHPsquares hashtag, you consent to and grant Instagram all rights to repost your photo or video. If you include music in your video submissions, please only use music to which you own the rights. Any tagged photo or video shared over the weekend with the #WHPsquares hashtag is eligible for the project and, if selected, to be featured next week.

Photo by @evakosmasflores
Eva Kosmas Flores‚Äô (@evakosmasflores) food philosophy = seasonal and local. ‚ÄúWhen we eat seasonally and support local farmers and growers, there are so many awesome things that happen,‚Äù says Eva. ‚ÄúOur meals taste infinitely better. Your local community‚Äôs economy grows. You‚Äôre eating nutrient-dense foods. And you‚Äôre helping the environment by reducing carbon emissions that come from shipping food all over the world.‚Äù
This year for #Thanksgiving, Eva will head to her parents‚Äô house with her husband ‚Äî the couple recently bought 29 aces (12 hectares) of logged forest they plan to restore to a healthy forest ‚Äî plus a mix of friends and family. ‚ÄúI love that we all get to gather around a beautiful meal and enjoy the last of all the tasty autumn foods altogether.‚Äù
Check out the scene in Eva‚Äôs kitchen today on our Instagram story. ü¶ÉüçÅ

Photo by @imfaridhasan
University student Farid Hasan (@imfaridhasan) created this image for #WHPcommunity with five new friends he met on Instagram. ‚ÄúIt was great to be able to photograph their joy,‚Äù he says. üôå

Photo by @kutovakika
‚ÄúWithout the community I‚Äôve found and built on Instagram, I would‚Äôve never started to take these kind of slightly whimsical and dreamy photos,‚Äù says photographer and content creator Veronika Lindberg (@kutovakika), who lives in London. ‚ÄúSeeing other people taking inspiration from them is just so exciting to me.‚Äù #WHPcommunity

Photo by @mar_laza
Mar Laza (@mar_laza) captured this moment on a hike in the Pyrenees mountains. ‚ÄúI love seeing older children helping and taking care of the little ones,‚Äù says Mar. ‚ÄúMy daughter was very tired and a friend, older than her, offered to take her on her back.‚Äù
Follow along as we feature more of our favorite submissions to last weekend's hashtag project, #WHPcommunity.

Photo by @chiyo.mame
Hello, world! It‚Äôs time for today‚Äôs #WeeklyFluff. Meet Mamechiyo, Karin, Marron, Melon, Yuzu, Fubuki, Toro, Mikan, Monaka and Kikuhiko ‚Äî the 10 cats (üòª!) that make up Mutsumi‚Äôs (@chiyo.mame) family. Check out today‚Äôs story to see these cool cats in action.

Photo by @camerawalebhaiya
A helping hand makes all the difference in this #WHPcommunity submission from 19-year-old Soumesh Pandey (@camerawalebhaiya). ‚ÄúThe essence of power within the frame encouraged me to take the shot,‚Äù he explains. ‚ÄúIt depicts how in every bad situation you can fight back if you get help from your surroundings.‚Äù

Photo by @viena_
When in doubt, go on a good walk through the trees with a good friend. #WHPcommunity

Photo by @est0y
‚ÄúBeing an expat and working far away from my family and country is hard. I‚Äôve been living and working in Dubai for the past 12 years,‚Äù says Mark Hebres (@est0y), an interior designer who is originally from the Philippines. ‚ÄúThe good thing is, during this period, I‚Äôve met people who I can turn to through the good times and bad times.‚Äù
Follow along as we share more of our favorite submissions to last weekend‚Äôs hashtag project, #WHPcommunity.

Photo of @zarialynn by @quinnmb
Growing up and traveling to far-off places instilled a love of landscape in artist Zaria Forman (@zarialynn). ‚ÄúMy mother was a fine-art photographer, she was very interested in really remote landscapes and getting as far away from cities and people as she could for her photography. Every summer for about one month, we would travel to pretty remote places,‚Äù says Zaria, who is based in Brooklyn, New York, and documents climate change through her pastel work. ‚ÄúWe take action to make decisions based on our emotions more than anything else. I have this special ability with my talent as an artist to tap into emotions, because that‚Äôs what art does.‚Äù
To learn more about Zaria‚Äôs art and process, check out today‚Äôs story and our IGTV channel.

Featured photo by @viajante_carioca
Weekend Hashtag Project: #WHPcommunity
The goal this weekend is to make photos and videos that celebrate togetherness, positivity and treating others with kindness. Our project takes inspiration from the Kering Foundation‚Äôs annual White Ribbon For Women campaign, which raises awareness of violence against women each November.
Here are some tips to get inspired:
Focus on your local community. Create images that show how your peers are standing up for one another and coming together.
Document kind interactions that show compassion like providing a shoulder for someone to lean on, or a group hug.
Find ways to express positivity. Whether it‚Äôs capturing small acts of kindness, like a big smile between two friends, or seeking out props that symbolize peace, like the campaign‚Äôs white ribbon. Also consider other emblems that illustrate a sense of tranquility within your image or video.
PROJECT RULES: Please add the #WHPcommunity hashtag only to photos and videos shared over this weekend and only submit your own visuals to the project. By adding the #WHPcommunity hashtag, you consent to and grant Instagram all rights to repost your photo or video. If you include music in your video submissions, please only use music to which you own the rights. Any tagged photo or video shared over the weekend with the #WHPcommunity hashtag is eligible for the project and, if selected, to be featured next week.
Tonight, we‚Äôre with Bad Bunny (@badbunnypr) in Las Vegas for the Latin Grammy Awards. Check out our story now to go behind the scenes as he prepped for the big night. #LatinGRAMMY

Photo by @billsmith2315
‚ÄúI really like that it‚Äôs not so much about the place as it is about the mood,‚Äù says William Smith (@billsmith2315) of his #WHPseasonal submission. ‚ÄúMany times I set out to capture a certain mood rather than the place. Here it‚Äôs the beauty of the fall, its atmosphere and the connection between a father and son taking photos together.‚Äù

Photo by @tamsynmorgans
‚ÄúI nipped into the garden and collected these leaves five minutes before shooting. They were still covered in dew!‚Äù says Tamsyn Morgans (@tamsynmorgans). ‚ÄúI love the expression on my daughter‚Äôs face. It was a really fun 10 minutes of creativity that we had before I got on with cooking lunch, and she carried on with her homework. It was a team effort to create this photo.‚Äù #WHPseasonal

Photo by @jlrainey
‚ÄúThe first snowfall of the year for Michigan happened on the day Instagram announced its weekend hashtag,‚Äù says Jessica Rainey (@jlrainey), who is a stay-at-home mom and photographer who lives in Detroit. ‚ÄúWinter is a favorite of mine, especially those early snowfalls. I wanted to capture those first glimpses of my daughter and give the photo as much wonder as I could.‚Äù
Follow along for more of our favorite submissions to last weekend‚Äôs hashtag project, #WHPseasonal.

Today on our IGTV channel: we‚Äôre on set with the stars of ‚ÄúRiverdale‚Äù (@thecwriverdale, @netflix) ‚Äî Lili Reinhart (@lilireinhart), Camila Mendes (@camimendes), Cole Sprouse (@colesprouse) and KJ Apa (@kjapa) ‚Äî talking all about their firsts. Tune in to learn about the cast‚Äôs first pets, first time getting grounded ü§Ø and more.

Photo by @ilkinkaracan
‚ÄúThe world is all about perspective,‚Äù says Turkish director and photographer Ilkin Karacan Karaku≈ü (@ilkinkaracan), who created this image on a photo walk. ‚ÄúSometimes we have to change our perspective for inspiration.‚Äù #WHPseasonal

Photo by @_fabiozingg
‚ÄúAutumn is my favorite time of the year, as all the colors in nature are more intense and so is the light in the Alps,‚Äù says Fabio Zingg (@_fabiozingg), who hiked five hours and camped out to get this shot for #WHPseasonal. ‚ÄúI loved waking up at this place and the composition with the light and fog.‚Äù

Photo by @cockapoomarley
‚ÄúMarley‚Äôs little nose just poking out of the oversized hood is how I feel through these autumn days,‚Äù says Marley‚Äôs (@cockapoomarley) human Katie Ramsden, ‚Äújust wanting to hide away from the rain and cold.‚Äù
Follow along for more of our favorite submissions to last weekend‚Äôs hashtag project, #WHPseasonal.

Illustration by @sublinhando
Today, we‚Äôre celebrating #WorldKindnessDay with S√£o Paulo-based illustrator Patricia Leda (@sublinhando). ‚ÄúWorld Kindness Day is a special day to remind us that we are not alone, that we are loved by our friends and our family,‚Äù she explains. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an opportunity to say something special to the people we like. It‚Äôs like a little reminder that we need to practice this every day.‚Äù
Head to our story to see the templates Patricia created for today‚Äôs holiday ‚ù§Ô∏è, then spread some kindness with the people in your üåé.

Photo by @leefromamerica 
Meet Los Angeles-based wellness enthusiast Lee Tilghman (@leefromamerica). Twenty-eight-year-old Lee is a self-proclaimed blogger, writer, photographer, workshop teacher, speaker and, yes, even human. ‚ÄúI was first introduced to the wellness space because of my struggle with an eating disorder between the ages of 16 and 18,‚Äù explains Lee. ‚ÄúAt 18, I started to learn what it felt like and what it looked like to treat my body with respect. That spurred a whole journey ‚Äî I‚Äôm still on it now ‚Äî of discovering and researching and really just playing along with different lifestyles and different ways of thinking and activities that made me feel my best... I know how to put my needs first, which is something that I didn‚Äôt necessarily know how to do before. And I feel confident and sure enough in myself to make those decisions and choices so that I can operate at the best possible version of myself.‚Äù Learn more about Lee‚Äôs self-care practice today on our story.

Weekend Hashtag Project: #WHPseasonal
Come rain or shine, this weekend‚Äôs challenge is to make images and videos that capture the spirit of the season in your region of the world, as in this featured photo illustration from Sandra (@salufi). Here are some tips to get started:
Focus on details that represent the season. For example, a single red leaf can represent fall, a strong shadow cast by the sun can feel like summer, or a crowded passageway full of open umbrellas can indicate the rainy season.
Play with seasonal activities. Get outside for apple picking, hiking or swimming, or if it‚Äôs very chilly where you live, stay inside and bundle up with your crew.
Let your palette set the mood. Whether it‚Äôs the changing hues of foliage in autumn, the snow-tipped mountain peaks in winter or a beachy summer day, capture the colors of the season in your photo or video.
PROJECT RULES: Please add the #WHPseasonal hashtag only to photos and videos shared over this weekend and only submit your own visuals to the project. By adding the #WHPseasonal hashtag, you consent to and grant Instagram all rights to repost your photo or video. If you include music in your video submissions, please only use music to which you own the rights. Any tagged photo or video shared over the weekend with the #WHPseasonal hashtag is eligible for the project and, if selected, to be featured next week.

Photo by @vineet_vohra
Vineet Vohra (@vineet_vohra) tried his hand at wildlife and fashion photography early in his career. But it wasn‚Äôt long before he was drawn to ‚Äúthe uncertainty and surprise‚Äù of street photography. ‚ÄúThe temporary connections I make in the street are more intense than what I found shooting wildlife,‚Äù says the photography teacher from New Delhi. ‚ÄúFor me, photography is not about sight. It‚Äôs about insight. My pictures are a dialogue, where I‚Äôm having a conversation with my audience, and with myself.‚Äù
A festival like #Diwali, the annual Hindu festival of lights, allows Vineet a deeper-than-usual dive into his culture. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not very religious,‚Äù he says, ‚Äúbut I am very spiritual. And as a photographer, anything having to do with light has huge significance in my life.‚Äù So Diwali, especially, resonates with him. ‚ÄúYou breathe for a while,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúYou think about the past year and moving into the next. There‚Äôs always negative energy around, even in good times, but the light during Diwali just washes it away. The light cleanses the soul.‚Äù
Check out today‚Äôs story to see what Diwali was like for Vineet. üì∏

Photo by @frauki
‚ÄúI absolutely love places that make you and your problems feel tiny, and think that nature has the power to put us back into place.‚Äù ‚ÄîGerman student Frauke Hameister (@frauki) #WHPscale

Photo by @mlnordan
‚ÄúWe reached into our nature box collection for inspiration for the WHP this week,‚Äù writes veterinarian Melissa Nordan (@mlnordan) in the caption to her #WHPscale submission. ‚ÄúAmongst our turtle shells, snake skins and bird nests we found these cicada wings to use. I lightly glued them onto a pane of glass and held it up in front of my camera as I photographed my daughter. It reminds me of summer. I can hear their ‚Äòsinging‚Äô as I type.‚Äù

Photo illustration by @dzalcman
‚ÄúThe kids look like they‚Äôre in the middle of some fairy tale landscape, lost among giant flowers and sparkling lights,‚Äù says photojournalist Daniella Zalcman (@dzalcman) of her #WHPscale submission, which is a composite of three images from Quinhagak, Alaska; Washington, DC; and Penobscot Nation, Maine. ‚ÄúI use multiple exposures in my editorial work on a regular basis and I also like to make these composites for fun ‚Äî particularly as a way to play with scale and give the images a slightly surreal feeling.‚Äù

Photo by @mydogstink
I spy Stink‚Äôs (@mydogstink) sandy tail? Or a giant furry‚ùì?
Follow along as we feature more of our favorite submissions to last weekend‚Äôs hashtag project, #WHPscale.

Photo by @studywithinspo
‚ÄúBullet journaling is for everyone,‚Äù says Brian Qian (@studywithinspo), a 17-year-old student in Southern California with a passion for keeping track of his lists, goals and to-dos with organized, artistic journaling. ‚ÄúWhether you have a full-time job or you‚Äôre a full-time parent, bullet journaling is a creative and effective way to organize your life,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúMy favorite thing about it is that I‚Äôm able to alter things when my life changes‚Äîduring the summer when I don‚Äôt have school, I minimize my weekly to-do lists because I don‚Äôt have that many assignments to finish.‚Äù Throughout the year, Brian‚Äôs journals are inspired by nature. ‚ÄúMy bullet journal reflects the seasons and the many things I love about nature, from mountains to flowers.‚Äù üåª
See more bullet journaling from Brian today on our story.

Weekend Hashtag Project: #WHPscale
This weekend, size matters. The challenge is to make images and videos that accentuate scale, like this photo illustration from Anastasia Kosh (@kosh_dp).
Here are some tips to get started:
Make images in places that naturally embody scale. Whether you're under the open sky, out on the ocean waves or in a redwood forest, look for opportunities to further accentuate scale by including small elements like a small figure or tiny cabin in your frame.
Focus on the little details. An eye looking through a magnifying glass, a single leaf falling from a tree or even a tiny car at a busy intersection can bring attention to the smaller things in the world that often get overlooked.
Be playful. Use things that are miniature or scale models of the real thing. Become a giant in a model village, hold a dollhouse in the palm of your hand, pluck a cotton wool cloud from the sky or play eye tricks to make unusual situations come to life.
PROJECT RULES: Please add the #WHPscale hashtag only to photos and videos shared over this weekend and only submit your own visuals to the project. By adding the #WHPscale hashtag, you consent to and grant Instagram all rights to repost your photo or video. If you include music in your video submissions, please only use music to which you own the rights. Any tagged photo or video shared over the weekend with the #WHPscale hashtag is eligible for the project and, if selected, to be featured next week.

Photo of @eljuanpazurita by @bryant 
Today, we're celebrating #D√≠aDeMuertos with the one and only Juanpa Zurita (@eljuanpazurita). üåπüíÄüåπ
On today's story and our IGTV channel, see Juanpa transform into ‚ÄúLa Catrina" skull makeup, and learn more about his connection to this sacred day. Check it out now.

Photo by @_mr.boo
BOO. üëª üèÄ #WHPdressup

Photo by @cozy_pastel
Time for a quick dance break before meeting with the coven. ‚ö°Ô∏è
Follow along as we feature more of our favorite submissions to last week's hashtag project #WHPdressup.

Photo by @maymothedog
Hello, world! It's time for a special #Halloween edition of #WeeklyFluff starring Maymo (@maymothedog). ‚ÄúMaymo lives in Massachusetts in a neighborhood next to a small pond and a trail where he enjoys eating sticks and the occasional roll in putrid things he finds in the grass,‚Äù explains Maymo's human, Jeremy. ‚ÄúMaymo enjoys planning the capture and eventual imprisonment of our mail carrier, as well as lobbying the government to put an end to bath time. He also enjoys smelling, staring at and eating food.‚Äù
This beagle also loves costumes and Halloween. ‚ÄúBecause of his proficiency in doggie disguises, Maymo is working on a tell-all memoir documenting his methods of canine costumery,‚Äù says Jeremy. Watch today‚Äôs story and our IGTV channel to see more costumed looks from Maymo.

Photo by @sienna.and.i
Ooooh! A sweet, spooky, ‚Äúscare-wee‚Äù submission to #WHPdressup. ü¶á

Photo by @chuchopotts
‚ÄúMy inspiration is what I see around me and the work of my friends,‚Äù says photographer Jesus Alberto Reyes Hernandez (@chuchopotts), who captured a photo of performance artist Butch Locsin (@butch_locsin_from_la) for #WHPdressup.

Photo by @schmitt.happenss
‚ÄúIf you've got it, haunt it,‚Äù writes Bethany Li (@schmitt.happenss) in the caption of her #WHPdressup submission that stars Schmitt, her dog. ‚ÄúSchmitt is so patient he will do almost anything!‚Äù
Follow along as we feature more of our favorite submissions to last week's hashtag project. üëª

Photo by @samanthachiu
Samantha Chiu (@samanthachiu) didn't grow up in a family of bakers. But when she began experimenting four years ago, she knew she‚Äôd found more than a hobby. ‚ÄúBaking has been, and will always be, a creative outlet for me,‚Äù says the 27-year-old software marketer who lives in Toronto, Canada.
Baking cookies and cakes in animal shapes allows Samantha's imagination to roam ‚Äî while keeping her ideas manageable. ‚ÄúConstraints breed creativity,‚Äù she says of her cute, minimalist designs. ‚ÄúI find it easier to challenge myself by setting boundaries.‚Äù
Ultimately, Samantha shares her creations with a simple goal in mind. ‚ÄúI just want to brighten someone‚Äôs day. If I‚Äôm able to make one person smile, then I feel like I‚Äôve accomplished something.‚Äù
Watch Samantha design and bake Halloween-themed creatures today on our story.

Photo by @makeup_by_rups
She's a tax advisor by day, but in her free time, Rupinder Ashan (@makeup_by_rups) uses body paint and makeup to transform into ghouls, demigods and figures from ancient myth. Spending up to seven hours on her simplest looks ‚Äî and twice that on more intricate efforts ‚Äî Rupinder immerses herself so fully in the work that she calls it ‚Äúthe ultimate form of meditation.‚Äù
The self-taught makeup artist also discovered an unexpected benefit to her art: a deeper appreciation of her own culture. ‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt until I started body painting that I rediscovered my roots. I really wasn't interested in my Indian heritage. Now, it's a big part of the conversation I want to put across. The deeper I dig, the more I find, and the richer it becomes.‚Äù
Watch Rupinder create a Halloween look today on story and new to our IGTV channel.

Photo by @birduyen ‚ÄúMy work has a very warm and calm atmosphere,‚Äù says Theresa ‚ÄúT‚Äù Le (@birduyen), ‚Äúlike when the sunlight is on your face in the morning, while the birds are softly chirping. I say that because I wouldn‚Äôt describe my art as striking or dynamic. Rather, I aim to create a peaceful and soft feeling.‚Äù A recent university graduate with a degree in statistics, T is taking part in #Inktober, an annual drawing challenge where artists all over the world create one ink each day of October. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs so inspiring to see all the different techniques and art styles that are showcased,‚Äù she explains. ‚ÄúI really wanted to be a part of that community, so I‚Äôm trying my best to be consistent, but also experimenting and having fun with my art during this spooky time of the year.‚Äù Check out today's story to see more of T's spooky and soothing art.

Weekend Hashtag Project: #WHPdressup
As many places around the world prepare to celebrate Halloween, it's time to tap into your imagination, and bring your dreams to life with videos and images, like this photo from Melissa Semi√£o (@theewhitewitch). Here are some tips to get started:
Dream up a new character. You can transform into a fantastical creature, a beautiful apparition or even an optical illusion ‚Äî there are no limits.
Rely on props. A sheet can transform your little brother into a ghost, a broom can make your best friend a witch, or a classic toothy jack-o'-lantern can set a spooky mood. 
Create a scene. Think about locations like a foggy forest or a dark room with dramatic lighting to add the desired atmosphere to your submission.

PROJECT RULES: Please add the #WHPdressup hashtag only to photos and videos shared over this weekend and only submit your own visuals to the project. By adding the #WHPdressup hashtag, you consent to and grant Instagram all rights to repost your photo or video. If you include music in your video submissions, please only use music to which you own the rights. Any tagged photo or video shared over the weekend with the #WHPdressup hashtag is eligible for the project and, if selected, to be featured next week.

Photo by @luna_thelurcher
Hello, world! Meet Luna (@luna_thelurcher), a two-year-old pup that loves chasing birds and squirrels at home in Kent, England. ‚ÄúA couple of things about Luna,‚Äù starts Luna's human Chris, ‚ÄúShe's really empathetic. If a person is crying, Luna will try to lick them better! It usually works. We think she could be a good therapy dog. Also, she talks a lot. If we've been out too long, she will tell us off with her best impression of Chewbacca.‚Äù

‚ÄúI guess I was born to do this!‚Äù says Berlin-based DJ and producer Peggy Gou (@peggygou_), who is originally from South Korea. While studying fashion in London, Peggy fell in love with house music. ‚ÄúI used to listen to a lot of K-pop. I listened to EDM. I listened to hip-hop. But moving to London, it got me into the house and techno scene.‚Äù Today, Peggy travels the world, creating music and connecting with fans. ‚ÄúThis is my second time at Amsterdam Dance Event (@amsterdamdanceevent). But I've played in Amsterdam quite a lot, and it's also one of my favorite cities to play. I love the crowd.‚Äù
Check out today's story and our IGTV channel to learn more about Peggy. ‚ö°Ô∏è

Photo by @darklydreamingdaniel
It's time. The sun must set on #WHPmirrorimage magic. üåÖ ‚ÄúIt was a beautiful sunset even though it was kind of cold in the water,‚Äù says photographer Daniel Nystr√∂m (@darklydreamingdaniel) from Stockholm, Sweden. ‚ÄúBut I had a brave model.‚Äù

Photo by @funkyspion
‚ÄúI‚Äôm a great fan of my city Warsaw and always try to find new places not explored by me before,‚Äù says Polish economist Mariusz Majewski (@funkyspion), who noticed a hotel's reflection on the hood of a nearby car. ‚ÄúSometimes, all you need is to take a look from a new perspective.‚Äù

Photo by @arunsharmaht
Photojournalist Arun Sharma (@arunsharmaht) spotted the perfect #WHPmirrorimage opportunity next to the Yamuna River.

Photo by @lyndaaa13
‚ÄúA sister is both your mirror and your opposite,‚Äù writes Lynda Molenaar (@lyndaaa13 ), an aspiring photographer from the Netherlands. This #WHPmirrorimage submission features her two daughters who are 9 and 12.

Photo by @hellohoku
Shiba Inu Hoku (@hellohoku)'s human Jennifer Ha found her #WHPmirrorimage inspiration while brainstorming Halloween costume ideas. ‚ÄúI thought we could plan something around these cool, retro glasses," she explains, ‚ÄúFigured I'd get his opinion, too.‚Äù

Photo by @tahiafarhin
‚ÄúI am a feminist, and I want to help for equality for all genders. I want to show that through my work,‚Äù says Tahia Farhin Haque (@tahiafarhin), one of the photographers who took part in ‚ÄúThis is 18,‚Äù a project from The New York Times (@nytgender). ‚Äú‚ÄòThis is 18‚Äô is about showing what girls go through all over the world when they turn 18 ‚Äî being 18 is a crucial stage for all of us,‚Äù says 22-year-old Tahia, who studies biochemistry and biotechnology in Dhaka, Bangladesh.
‚ÄúI hope to give voice to the issues that are unheard and unseen in the world. I would like to make people question their perceptions and the paradigms. I work towards a goal to shatter traditional stereotypes about women in order to bring their unique perspectives to the forefront.‚Äù
Watch today‚Äôs story to see more from Tahia.

Featured photo by @lennart
#Weekend Hashtag Project: #WHPmirrorimage
This weekend, the goal is to take photos and make videos that play with reflections and mirror the world around us, as in this image from Lennart Pagel (@lennart).
Look for reflections at different scales. Whether it‚Äôs a mountain peak reflected in the still waters of an epic landscape or a silhouette standing tall in a cafe window, mirror images can be seen and photographed in lots of different places. Keep your eyes peeled.
Think about the light and mood. A sun-drenched landscape captured in a rearview mirror fuels a very different feeling than a still portrait framed by a vintage full-length mirror.
Play with perspective. Bring mirrors into nature to explore optical illusions or capture a warped or distorted image, or use multiple mirrors and reflections to create your own ‚Äúhall of mirrors,‚Äù a kaleidoscopic image with an infinity reflection.
PROJECT RULES: Please add the #WHPmirrorimage hashtag only to photos and videos shared over this weekend and only submit your own visuals to the project. By adding the #WHPmirrorimage hashtag, you consent to and grant Instagram all rights to repost your photo or video. Photo of @stephencurry30 by @rover
‚ÄúFor me, being a Warrior now means being a champion,‚Äù says Golden State Warrior Stephen Curry (@stephencurry30). ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs holding yourself to a high standard, expecting greatness out of yourself, being prepared, disciplined.‚Äù The three-time NBA (@nba) champion and two-time MVP grew up in Charlotte, North Carolina, but the San Francisco Bay Area has been home since the start of his professional basketball career. ‚ÄúThis is the place that kind of shaped me in that respect,‚Äù says Stephen of the Bay Area. ‚ÄúI hope to obviously play here for the rest of my career, but once it‚Äôs all said and done, retire, hopefully a lot of more years, I‚Äôll probably still stay out here. Because just the people are so cool, there‚Äôs so much to do, good food, you can travel all over the Bay, get a different vibe. There are so many different pockets that show you so much love.‚Äù
To celebrate the tip off of this year‚Äôs basketball season, we‚Äôre at home and on the court with Stephen. See more on today‚Äôs story and our IGTV channel.

A trip into a cookbook store when he was 10 years old changed chef Flynn McGarry‚Äôs (@diningwithflynn) life. ‚ÄúI picked the most expensive cookbook on the top shelf ‚Äì ‚ÄòThe French Laundry Cookbook.‚Äô With that, cooking changed for me from no longer being just about what you eat to being an art form.‚Äù Today, the 19-year-old who was born in Los Angeles now lives in NYC and spends his days dreaming up concepts and cooking up inventive dishes at his restaurant, Gem.

See what life is like for chef Flynn these days on our IGTV channel.

Featured photo by @denisebovee
Weekend Hashtag Project: #WHPkindness
This weekend, the goal is to come together and make images and videos that embody friendship and compassion, as in this image by Denise Bovee (@denisebovee). Here are some tips to get you started:
Come together. Get together with a group of family members, friends or classmates to enjoy each other‚Äôs company through an activity that lends itself to visuals, like a picnic in your favorite park.
Show support. Do a good deed while you‚Äôre with your people. Shelter someone under an umbrella or give someone a gift. It can even be as simple as sharing a hug with someone who needs it.
Get creative. Build your image around a giant heart, incorporate flowers in your composition or include symbolic motifs like the image of a butterfly or rainbow to give your video or photo an optimistic tone.
PROJECT RULES: Please add the #WHPkindness hashtag only to photos and videos shared over this weekend and only submit your own visuals to the project. If you include music in your video submissions, please only use music to which you own the rights. Any tagged photo or video shared over the weekend is eligible to be featured next week.

Over the years, Misty Copeland (@mistyonpointe) has performed ‚ÄúThe Nutcracker‚Äù ballet in many different roles: Clara, the Sugar Plum Fairy, a doll, Marzipan, a flower, a Spanish dancer and a snowflake. ‚ÄúIt was the first ballet I performed in,‚Äù says the principal dancer. ‚ÄúIt was the most enchanting and empowering feeling I had ever experienced.‚Äù
Now, in the film ‚ÄúThe Nutcracker and the Four Realms,‚Äù she performs in a new role as the Ballerina Princess. ‚ÄúI hope that with ‚ÄòThe Nutcracker and the Four Realms,‚Äô people see the story through fresh eyes, with the film bringing beauty and diversity to the screen.‚Äù

Today is #DayOfTheGirl ‚Äî a United Nations holiday close to the causes Malala Yousafzai (@malala) champions, like girls‚Äô education and women‚Äôs equality. ‚ÄúI wish more people knew what girls face every day. 130 million girls can‚Äôt go to school. The hardest thing is to meet a girl nearly my age, with all the dreams and aspirations that I have, stuck in a situation she didn‚Äôt create and unable to choose her own future. And I‚Äôve met thousands of girls like this,‚Äù says Malala. ‚ÄúYou see a lot of feminist hashtags and T-shirts. But if we really believe the future is female or that girls run the world, we need to support girls on the frontlines of the fight for education and equality.‚Äù
Today on our story, we‚Äôre hanging out with Malala, learning about some of the latest and greatest moments and people in her life. üåç

Featured photo by @brianhardd
Weekend Hashtag Project: #WHPunusualportraits
This weekend, the goal is to make surprising still or video portraits, as in this image by Brian Hardimas Permadi (@brianhardd). Here are some tips:
Go somewhere out of the box. Think about unusual places and situations, like underwater, in a hall of mirrors or the middle of a crowded party, to make your final product surprising.
Include distinctive details. Dress up or get creative with props, makeup or lighting to make your portrait more distinctive. Use colorful accessories, surround your eyes with flower petals or wear two pairs of overlapping sunglasses.
Get creative within the frame. Play with hand or body positions to make your portrait pop. Get close up in someone‚Äôs smile, crop your portrait to see half a face in the frame or shoot from different directions and angles to create something unique.
PROJECT RULES: Please add the #WHPunusualportraits hashtag only to photos and videos shared over this weekend and only submit your own visuals to the project. If you include music in your video submissions, please only use music to which you own the rights. Any tagged photo or video shared over the weekend is eligible to be featured next week.

Photo by @conchitaqween
‚ÄúMy culture is very present in my fashion,‚Äù says Los Angeles native Sailor Gonzales (@conchitaqween), who‚Äôs in school studying fashion design and Chicano studies. ‚ÄúMy generation spends money on things that they believe in and things that they can connect to. I really love that about the Chicano culture, because we appreciate a garment as it is a work of art, not necessarily just that it‚Äôs a shirt. We see the embroidery and the time that it took to make that ‚Äî and then wearing it, and understanding the traditions, and how weaving has been passed down through generations. I love that we can appreciate that, and most importantly, pay up for that.‚Äù
This month, we‚Äôre sharing stories of Hispanic-American community members in celebration of #HispanicHeritageMonth, which runs through October 15 in the US.
Today on our story and on our IGTV channel, we‚Äôre skating around Los Angeles with Sailor learning about her life and her connection to Chicano culture. #MiVoz #MyVoice

Photo by @nathan_thebeachcat

Soon after Nathan‚Äôs humans brought her home, they started taking trips to the beach. ‚ÄúWe wanted her to be able to experience that great outdoors rather than solely being a house cat,‚Äù says one of Nathan‚Äôs humans, Melissa. And luckily, for Nathan, it was love at first swim. ‚ÄúMy partner Rian walked into the water, and Nathan just followed him out without any hesitation,‚Äù says Melissa. ‚ÄúIt was very cute! From there she just got more and more confident in the water, coming out further and further until she eventually started swimming.‚Äù

Photo by @itslizmiu
‚ÄúI prioritize happiness, health, creativity and success ‚Äî in that order,‚Äù says Liz Miu (@itslizmiu), a 25-year-old vegan cook and blogger. Liz shares moments from her daily life in Sydney, Australia, including everything from vegan recipes to self-care tips to ways to reduce plastic waste. ‚ÄúI like to think of my Instagram as evolving with me. It‚Äôs a journey of me becoming my best self.‚Äù
If Liz were to recommend one small change people make to their daily lives, it would be to make time for meditation. ‚ÄúMeditation has been transformative for me,‚Äù says Liz. ‚ÄúI think all health and happiness comes from within you. Just sit with yourself for 10 minutes a day, and you‚Äôll figure out who you are. You‚Äôll strengthen yourself from the inside.‚Äù
Learn how Liz makes all-natural deodorant today on our story and watch how she makes vegan granola on our IGTV channel. To watch IGTV, update your app now, then look for the new icon in the top right corner of feed.

Today is the end of an incredible chapter in our story. Our co-founders @kevin and @mikeyk are leaving the company they founded eight years ago. A new leader, Adam Mosseri, with a background in design and a love of simplicity and craft ‚Äî two elements essential to Instagram ‚Äî is now taking the reins. Congratulations and good luck @mosseri. And thank you Kevin and Mike for all that you have done for all of us. Thanks as well to our community of a billion for being part of this next chapter, too.

Featured photo by @princejyesi
Weekend Hashtag Project: #WHPmatching
This weekend, we‚Äôre seeing double. üëÄ The goal is to create photos and videos that show the power of a pair, as in this image by Prince Gyasi (@princejyesi). Here are some tips for the project:
Get twinning. Whether you dress up friends identically or capture a mirror image of the moon on a lake, get creative with how the concept of ‚Äútwinning‚Äù can show up in photos and videos.
Consider classic duos. Find objects that come together for your composition. Think of a knife and fork, cereal and milk, or even sticks and stones.
Match unlikely pairs. Go beyond identical images or classic duos by playing with the way people and objects relate. Take a photo of a friend in a green sweater enjoying a matcha ice-cream cone, or have a sibling stretch out in the same shape of your favorite backyard tree.
PROJECT RULES: Please add the #WHPmatching hashtag only to photos and videos shared over this weekend and only submit your own visuals to the project. If you include music in your video submissions, please only use music to which you own the rights. Any tagged photo or video shared over the weekend is eligible to be featured next week.
